author: ThomasNieto
body:
# PR Summary

This PR is the second-half of #4716 to add `[SupportsWildcards]` attribute to all parameters that support wildcards.

## PR Context

The `[SupportsWildcards]` attribute is queried by the help system to inform the user if wildcards are supported. The list of parameters was generated by @sdwheeler.

- [x] [PR has a meaningful title](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)

    - **OR**
    - [ ] [Make sure you've added a new test if existing tests do not effectively test the code changed](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#before-submitting)
- **Tooling**
    - [x] I have considered the user experience from a tooling perspective and don't believe tooling will be impacted.
    - **OR**

comments.body: @sdwheeler To test if they have the attribute applied or that the help system is picking it up?

comments.author: sdwheeler
comments.body: @ThomasNieto Testing the output of the Help System should be easy enough. I am more concerned about the accuracy of the list I created. Is that list accurate and complete? How do we test new parameters and cmdlets to ensure that `[SupportsWildcards]` is correct?

comments.author: ThomasNieto
comments.body:
@sdwheeler This PR #13353 has tests to verify if the help system is properly identifying if a cmdlet has this attribute or not. To verify I had added the attribute to the correct parameters I used a PS script to gather the globbing value from the help system. If external help is present it uses what you put in the maml. I compared the output to your list and caught a couple of extra parameters. As for ensuring that the attribute is added on new parameters and cmdlets I'm not sure about the best way to do that.

@vexx32 had an idea to remove the need to have this attribute at all in #4715. If it was the pre-1.0 days to have parameters use `WildcardPattern` as the parameter type. As a related suggestion we could have a generic type of `[Wildcard<T>]` so the module author can indicate at the type level if wildcards are supported. The generic type could have properties/methods that wrap or use `WildcardPattern` to validate `IsMatch()`. There are a couple of examples in the PS code where the input type of a wildcard parameter is not a string. Those cases use an argument transform attribute.

comments.author: rjmholt
comments.body:
> As a related suggestion we could have a generic type of [Wildcard<T>] so the module author can indicate at the type level if wildcards are supported

This and a similar type for paths are something I'd really like to see. Something with an implicit conversion from string I don't think would cause any breaks.

We should probably move discussion on that to an issue.

comments.author: sdwheeler
comments.body:
> Testing the output of the Help System should be easy enough. I am more concerned about the accuracy of the list I created. Is that list accurate and complete? How do we test new parameters and cmdlets to ensure that `[SupportsWildcards]` is correct?

As I said in a previous comment, I was concerned about the accuracy of the list. The list was built based on the existing documentation. If the documentation is not accurate then neither is the list. We need someone to verify how the parameters actually work and add the attribute where appropriate. The list was an attempt at limiting the scope of the effort instead of having to review every parameter of every cmdlet.

comments.author: rjmholt
comments.body: I think rather than keeping this PR open, it might be best to go through the original list, validate it to create a new list, and then create a PR based on that

comments.author: rjmholt
comments.body: I'm going to close this PR, since I don't think we're ready to consider code changes yet. Let's go through the process of verifying the parameters in an issue, which is a better format than a PR for such a discussion.
